answers.body_markdown:
Few code improvements you can do:

1) Use *ES6* syntax wherever possible. For example, *let*, *const*, *fat arrow function*.
2) In your DOM there is only one hamburger class. So, instead of using *getElementsByClassName* and looping over that. You can use the *querySelector()*. 
Also, you have taken the hamburger class referenced twice  :

    var coll = document.getElementsByClassName("hamburger");

    var hamburger = document.querySelector(".hamburger");
3) You have defined the click handler logic twice in your code. Both can be merged. 
So, below both code blocks can be merged into the one.

    coll[i].addEventListener("click", function() {...}
    hamburger.addEventListener("click", function() {...}

4) `document.onload = document.getElementsByClassName("mobilemenuspace")[0].style.display = "none";` 

You don't need to do this in JavaScript. In CSS, in the *mobilemenuspace*  class just add `display:none`

5) `document.getElementsByClassName("mobilemenuspace")[0]` Again as there is only 1 mobilemenuspace you want to target you can use `document.querySelector`. 

This will help in making your code less in lines and better wrt to the right use of the syntax and methods. For the animation part, you are doing toggling of the classes which are correct. As CSS animations are less expensive then JS animations. What you can look into is having more smoothness while toggling in CSS only. 

Thanks,
NS

answers.body_markdown:
I'm making some assumptions about your objectives, because your code has an object `SearchCoord` which you don't provide, so I assumed that was `SpeciesCoord`.

With the `geodist` function, you can have a vector of coordinates for one of the reference points, making your double loop unnecessary. So for example, the following code gives the distance from the 1st locality to all of the species (you can do vice versa, so give all the localities and one species, but unfortunately I don't think you can give vectors for both):

    geodist(RefCoord$Latitude[1],RefCoord$Longitude[1],SpeciesCoord$latS,SpeciesCoord$longE,units="km")

So you can calculate all of the distances into a list, then construct a matrix based off logical conditions with that list:

    dist_list <- lapply(1:nrow(RefCoord), function(i) geodist(RefCoord$Latitude[i],RefCoord$Longitude[i],SpeciesCoord$latS,SpeciesCoord$longE,units="km"))
    
    mat <- matrix(unlist(lapply(dist_list, function(val) as.numeric(val <= 600))), nrow = 6, ncol = 6, byrow = T)
    
    colnames(mat) = SpeciesCoord$Species
      
    rownames(mat) = RefCoord$Locality

For the data you provided, none of the species are within 20 km, so I changed it to 600 to show that the code should work

Following this shortcut makes possible: (b) Each part of the three-part expression (e.g., `RETURN-TYPE (POINTER-DECLARATION)(LIST-OF-ARGUMENT-TYPES);`) should contain **one set of parentheses** except for the leftmost term which contains **no parentheses**, and the middle term of the expression is the name of the variable (and therefore containers the asterisk[`*`]) for instance, `int (*_mainPtr)(int, const char *[]);` should define a pointer to the `main` function in your program.

answers.body_markdown:
IMO, your window definition is wrong. You should partition by the column with which you want to make groups of, and then collect a set of unique values per group. 

IIUC, you just need to do:

```
w = Window.partitionBy(['id', 'country']).orderBy('date')

sorted_list_df = df.withColumn('sorted_list', F.collect_set('action').over(w))

df_new = sorted_list_df.select('id', 'country', 'sorted_list').withColumn("count_of_elems", F.size("sorted_list"))
```

**DRAWBACK**:

If you use a window, you will have a new set for every row, and your row count is going to be the same as the old df. There is not going to be an aggregation per se, since I don't think that's not what you want too.

This next line aggregates the values as a set for every group. I'm hoping it gets you exactly what you want:
```
df_new = sorted_list_df.groupby('id', 'country').agg(F.max('sorted_list').alias('sorted_list')).withColumn("count_of_elems", F.size("sorted_list"))
```

answers.body_markdown:
It sounds like you are trying to add a column to a table that has already been created via migration. If that is the case, rather than using `Schema::create(...)`, you need to use `Schema::table(...)`.

Typically, you would create a new migration for this:
```shell
$ php artisan make:migration add_img_url_to_categories
```

Which will create a new file at `/database/migrations` called something like `2019_10_21_165554_add_img_url_to_categories.php`. Then add this code to the `up()` function:

```php
public function up()
{
  Schema::table('categories', function (Blueprint $table) {
    $table->string('img_url');
  });
}
```
---
Another option you have is to edit the migration exactly as you have done (per the code in your question), and then run:

```shell
$ php artisan migrate:fresh // drop all tables and re-run all migrations
```
or

```shell
$ php artisan migrate:refresh // reset and re-run all migrations
```

But keep in mind that ***these are both destructive operations***  meaning you will lose any data you already have in your database. In early development, that might not matter. But you should really establish the habit of creating ***new*** migrations for database changes, rather than editing existing migrations.

The purpose of migrations is so that you (or anyone using your app) can quickly deploy a database that matches the schema your app is expecting. 
During development, it is not uncommon to edit your migrations as you tweak your database schema to accommodate the features you are developing.

However, once you have deployed or published your app, you should consider all of the migrations to be locked or read-only. Any database changes from that point should be done in a ***new*** migration.

answers.body_markdown:
You're correct, jQuery ajax will "fail" if it receives an HTTP 503 ... or 500, or 404, etc.  It will also (obviously) fail on ECONNREFUSED or any socket-level (communications) error.

Here is the documentation:

> https://api.jquery.com/jquery.ajax/
> 
> **jQuery.ajax()**: Perform an asynchronous HTTP (Ajax) request.
> 
>  `jqXHR.fail(function( jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown ) {});`
> 
> An alternative construct to the error callback option, the .fail()
> method replaces the deprecated .error() method. Refer to
> deferred.fail() for implementation details.
> 
> https://api.jquery.com/deferred.fail/
> 
> **deferred.fail()**:  Add handlers to be called when the Deferred object is rejected.

It's worth noting that the connection can succeed ... the server can return HTTP 200/OK ... and your jQuery Ajax call can *STILL* trigger a "fail".

For example, if you're expecting a JSON response, and the server returns XML:

https://www.mkyong.com/jquery/jquery-ajax-request-return-200-ok-but-error-event-is-fired/

ADDITIONAL INFO:

* To answer your original question: Yes, "success" generally implies an HTTP 200. 

* But a lot of different things besides a non-HTTP 200 can trigger a "fail". 

* You can even have an HTTP 200 and still "fail" (per the link above).

* Or have a non-HTTP 200 and still "succeed" (for example, [HTTP 201](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/201)).

* HTTP 304, is a "special case". Look [here][1] or [here][2]. 

Q: Is your question answered? 


  [1]: https://www.telerik.com/blogs/understanding-http-304-responses
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/201

answers.body_markdown:
This is explained in [Query Formatting], how one value versus array changes the values interpretation:

> This however works only for types `number`, `bigint`, `string`, `boolean`, `Date` and `null`, because types like `Array` and `Object` change the way parameters are interpreted.

    db.any(`SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN ($1:csv)`, team.member_ids)
    //=> SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN (1)

Because above you are passing in the value itself directly, `$1` refers to the first element in that array. To make `$1` refer to the entire value-array, that value itself needs to be inside an array:

    db.any(`SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN ($1:csv)`, [team.member_ids])
    //=> SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN (1,2)


Alternatively, the recommended use of [Named Parameters] makes the code more concise:

    db.any(`SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN ($<member_ids:csv>)`, team)
    //=> SELECT * FROM users WHERE user_id IN (1,2)

In general, use [pg-monitor] to see what queries are being executed.

[Named Parameters]:https://github.com/vitaly-t/pg-promise#named-parameters
[Query Formatting]:https://github.com/vitaly-t/pg-promise#query-formatting
[pg-monitor]:https://github.com/vitaly-t/pg-monitor

answers.body_markdown:
The simplest is to move the sort to the `row_number()`:

    select ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY [Depart Year], [Booking Year], [Sorter])) as x,
           CAST([Pax] as INT) as y,
           t.*
    --into #regression_data
    from #TBB_Temp t;

SQL tables represent *unordered* sets, so the outer `order by` does very little.

Another method adds an identity column instead:

    select identity(int) as x,
           CAST([Pax] as INT) as y,
           t.*
    --into #regression_data
    from #TBB_Temp t
    order by [Depart Year], [Booking Year], [Sorter];

The one exception to `order by` being meaningless for an `insert` is that `identity` respects the ordering.

Note that for both these methods, you *have to use `order by`* when querying the table:

    select rd.*
    from #regression_data rd
    order by x;

See above note on tables and unordered sets.

The [`filter`][1] function (called before `initscr`) tells curses to limit its updates to a single line.   The python binding includes [`filter`][2].

Here's an example:

    import curses
    
    curses.filter()
    stdscr = curses.initscr()
    curses.noecho()
    foo = stdscr.getkey()
    print("result:" + foo)


  [1]: https://invisible-island.net/ncurses/man/curs_util.3x.html#h3-filter_nofilter
  [2]: https://docs.python.org/2/library/curses.html#curses.filter

answers.title: Handle a object like dictionary

answers.body_markdown:
If you want to have a full dictionary-like behaviour (icluding indexing etc.) you can inherit from python dict:
```python
class FruitBasket(dict):
    pass
    

diz=FruitBasket()
diz = {"banana" : 3 , "apple" : 5,"mango" : 1, "orange" : 2}

diz = FruitBasket(diz)

print(diz)
# {'apple': 5, 'orange': 2, 'banana': 3, 'mango': 1}

print(diz['apple'])
# 5
```
This way it is de facto a dictionary but you can extend it with your own functionality.

answers.body_markdown:
It seems the compiler follows a pattern to decorate these exported functions. On a `x86` platform with a `_cdecl calling convention` for every function exported through `.def file` or `__declspec(dllexport)` the `.lib` file contains 2 entries. One as the function name prefixed with an `_` and another prefixed with `__imp__`

For example, if the `def file` has an exported function as `Function1` the lib will have `_Function1` and `__imp__Function1`

This will vary for `x64` and other function calling conventions.

With the above being said, mine was a peculiar case. My def file had `Object`, `_Object` and `__Object` which should result in `_Object`, `__imp__Object`, `__Object`, `__imp___Object`, `___Object` and `__imp____Object`.

Now from the above list, the 2nd actual name (`_Object`) and the the 1st generated name are same, so it was skipping generating symbols for the 2nd name. Hence I was getting the link error:

> error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol __imp___Object
answers.title: How many underscores ('_') in the exported function in C++

I have a function named `Object()` in my code for this Visual Studio seems to generate lot of versions like `__imp____Object`, `__imp___Object` and `__imp__Object`. I can't understand why so many versions.

The problem I am facing is even if I have added `___Object` and `__Object` in my `.def` file I am getting the following linker error:

Any suggestions, what's going on here.

answers.body_markdown:
Found the fix. It is called soapParameterStyle

    [WebMethod]
    [SoapDocumentMethod(ParameterStyle = SoapParameterStyle.Bare)]

Additionally, we have to switch off the wsi profiles to None.

    [WebServiceBinding(ConformsTo = WsiProfiles.None)]

 parameterStyle - Specifies how the method parameters, which correspond to message parts in a WSDL contract, are placed into the SOAP message body.

A parameter style of BARE means that each parameter is placed into the message body as a child element of the message root.

A parameter style of WRAPPED means that all of the input parameters are wrapped into a single element on a request message and that all of
    the output parameters are wrapped into a single element in the response message.

answers.body_markdown:
A couple of things could be happening. Have you created a ts.config.js with ts configuration and parser config, something like: 

     export const typescriptConfig = {
     extends: ['plugin:@typescript-eslint/eslint- 
     recommended'],
     overrides: [
       {
         parser: '@typescript-eslint/parser',
         extends: [
           'plugin:@typescript-eslint/recommended',
           'prettier/@typescript-eslint',
           'plugin:import/typescript',
         ],
         plugins: ['@typescript-eslint'],

         files: ['*.ts', '*.tsx'],

         rules: {},
       },
     ],
   }


Create React App uses ESLint by default. However, ESLint can't parse TypeScript by default. If you want, you may consider using @typescript-eslint/parser.

This could be that the base babel-eslint parser not working correctly without any config.
ESLint is not applying different parsers to different files, hence babel-eslint might be throwing an error.

Make sure your config file is created in the root of the project. I would start with that.

answers.title: Mailing lists with relations or not?

items.body_markdown:
I'm working with a system that keeps track of email "Recipients" in different "Mailing Lists".

Today we don't have a "many to many"-relationship between the Recipient and the Mailing Lists, if a recipient is in multiple lists they are treated as separate enteties in the system (so foo@bar.com could be added 3 times but connected to  different mailing lists).

I've started to question this approach and my idea is to create a "many to many" relationship between a Recipient and a "Mailing List". It seems reasonable in many ways to treat one email as the "primary key" (not technically in the db but on a conceptional level) and to avoid duplicated information as well.

After digging around in this space I've come to notice that big players in this field like MailChimp and Campaign Monitor is using the approach that we're currently using (unique entities per mailing list). So I'm getting a little "torn" in my opinion here. Their approach means that "meta data" like for example a city, zip code etc would be duplicated for the same Recipient in each Mailing List and a night mare to keep in sync. (We don't have any meta data today but its on the roadmap).

I would love to get some thoughts around these questions:

 1. Why are they storing the recipients like this? Is there any advantage to this approach that I'm missing? I could maybe see a scenario where one want to transfer a Mailing List to another "Account" but more than that..?

 2. What approach would you prefer if you would have been faced with the same challenge? Please give some motivations so I can learn from them.

Thank you very much!
items.title: Mailing lists with relations or not?

answers.body_markdown:
SQL Server has poor string processing functionality.  That is why it is better to process data when it goes into the database.

That said, you can do what you want.  Here is one method:

    select t.*, left(v1.str, charindex(' ', v1.str + ' ')) as codigo_str
    from (values ('[header]nombre=ATC Cargas MZA/TUC/SGO.TN.03/03/10 DEV codigo=ACLGO target=0 activo=1 VigenciaD')) t(str) cross apply
         (values (stuff(t.str, 1, charindex('codigo=', t.str + 'coldigo=') - 1, ''))) v1(str);

This chops off the string before the `'codigo='`.  It then uses `left()` to take everything up to the first space.

The use of concatenation within `charindex()` makes this safe if `'codigo='` is not in the string or not followed by a space.
answers.title: Select String value in SQL Server

answers.body_markdown:
Play around SQL built in functions, CHARINDEX and SUBSTRING. Logically, the following pseudocode should work: 

 1. Get the index where your keyword is placed alongside your entire string.
 2. From index, add the number or lenght of characters you used from your keyword.
 3. Substring the entire text from result of step number 2 up until to the number of desired lenght of text. If you're text is fixed then it would be easier.  

See [CHARINDEX][1] and [SUBSTRING][2].

Hope this helps.

  [1]: https://www.w3schools.com/sql/func_sqlserver_charindex.asp
  [2]: https://www.w3schools.com/sql/func_sqlserver_substring.asp
answers.title: Select String value in SQL Server

answers.body_markdown:
It depends on your needs. If you only want to push your commit to the master, 
The safest way is to use `cherry-pick` from your branch to the master. It's perfectly safe because you don't have to force-push.

1. Find the commit hash: `git log`.
2. Checkout to master: `git checkout master`.
3. Realign with master `git pull` or `git pull upstream master` if you're using upstream branch.
4. Check that you're aligned with master: `git status`.
5. Cherry pick without commit: `git cherry-pick -n <commit-hash>`
6. Commit: `git commit -m <commit message>`
6. Check the log, before pushing: `git log`. You can also check the diff: `git diff origin/master`.
7. Push to master: `git push`.
answers.title: 52 commits behind master

You can just use simple rebase comment for updating your local repo,

**`git pull --rebase --autostash`**

Sometimes you will get merge conflicts, don't worry you can resolve that manually and use `git rebase --continue`

"*52 commits behind the master*" this because your local repository is not up-to-date.
